Kayako - ticket id 60252140 // Andriy Rybalchenko commented publicly: Dear Jonard,

Thank you for your follow-up.

At this stage, a remote session would not provide meaningful diagnostic insight since the issue occurs within the PatchAgent operations or the LanGuard–PatchAgent communication process, which can only be confirmed through log analysis. Even though logs were shared before, we do need a scan results + fresh set after the previous log files were deleted to eliminate noise and concentrate on the current flow.

These logs will allow us to triage the issue and determine whether a remote session is necessary afterward.

Best regards,
Andriy Rybalchenko
GFI - LanGuard Support Team

This ticket will stay open for one week unless you reply with "This ticket can be closed" or update the status to Completed in the portal. We will write to you again to remind you.

Kayako - ticket id 60252140 // Andriy Rybalchenko commented publicly: Dear Jonard,

Thank you for the clarification. Before we analyze the logs reproducing the issue and additional diagnostic data, a remote session is not needed and won't be productive. Kindly ask the client to:

	*
Enable Debug Mode and delete the old logging data [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/122371-providing-troubleshooter-logs-from-gfi-languard-server] - all existing files from C:\ProgramData\GFI\LanGuard12\DebugLogs with the exception: DO NOT delete the HTTPD subfolder or the files inside it.

	*
Deleting old data really helps to reduce noise

	*
Backup and delete the PatchAgent.log file from the target machine (CGQUILIT), from C:\Windows\Patches\

	*
Reproduce the issue - scan the target machine from console, then remediate

	*
Kindly gather Troubleshooter Logs from GFI LanGuard Server [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/122371-providing-troubleshooter-logs-from-gfi-languard-server]  and provide the full .7z log archive generated by the troubleshooter for review

	* Export and share Scan Results in XML [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/122526-saving-and-loading-scan-results-in-xml].
	* Gather and share PatchAgent Logs from the target machine:

	*
Navigate to C:\Windows\Patches\

	*
After the remediation completes, attach the newly generated PatchAgent.log file to this ticket.

These files will help us confirm whether the issue occurs during patch verification or in communication between the PatchAgent and the LanGuard server. Once we have this data, we can analyze it and determine if a remote session is necessary.

Best regards,
Andriy Rybalchenko
GFI - LanGuard Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60252140 // Ibiso Barimalaa commented publicly: Dear Jonard,

Thank you for the logs. Here are the key findings.

Your Nov 27 deployment logs show all 3 patches (KB890830, Firefox 143.0.4, KB5066131) were successfully deployed to CGQUILIT:

	* Patches 1 & 2: Completed with Exit Status 0
	* Patch 3: Deployed successfully, but status message not received by LanGuard

Your video confirms these updates are installed in Windows Update.
image
The Windows malicious software removal tool update would be found under  Settings > Windows Update > Update History > Other update or Quality Update. 

The PatchAgent service completes the installations on the target machine, but the communication connection to LanGuard server likely closes prematurely before final status messages are sent back. This isn't a port blocking issue (since initial communication works fine) - it's the connection dropping during active deployment. As a result, patches install successfully, but LanGuard marks them "incomplete" because it never receives confirmation.

The uploaded PatchAgent.log stops at Nov 19, but your remediation was on Nov 27. So we are unable to see what happened during the connection closure.

Since we the updates did complete, please run a Full Scan on CGQUILIT as required as a remediation job; the console may be displaying outdated information. After the rescan:

	* These 3 patches should disappear from Remediation Center
	* We'll see the true current state

If you are still experiencing the issue, please provide 

	* Saving and loading scan results in xml [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/122526]

	* Backup and delete the PatchAgent.log file from the target machine (CGQUILIT) and proceed to perform the remediation again

	* Attach the C:\Windows\Patches\PatchAgent.log file located in the target machine.

	* The troubleshooter logs from GFI LanGuard server [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/122371]

Best regards,
Ibiso Barimalaa
GFI - LanGuard Support Team

This ticket will stay open for one week unless you reply with "This ticket can be closed" or update the status to Completed in the portal. We will write to you again to remind you.

 From the video, we can see that the Windows update is there 
image 
 The Windows malicious software removal tool update would be found under  Settings > Windows Update > Update History > Other update or Quality Update. 

 It appears that the 3 updates completed but the connection to the LanGuard close before it could get a response from the target machine. Since the patchagent.log entry stops on Nov 17, we can't verify at what stage the connection closed. 

 I would recommend rescanning the machine because it doesn't make sense remediating updates that has already been installed (i.e. firefox and windows malicious software removal tool update). The expectation is that these updates should no longer be available for remediation.

Kayako - ticket id 60252140 // Keyur Saxena commented publicly: Hello Jonard,

That looks like a corporate firewall blocking the connection. I confirm I was able to access the SFTP location successfully with no VPN/special firewalls. LanGuard does not update the Windows Update history in Settings:

image

That is done by Windows Update itself. However, you will be able to see the patches in Control Panel > Programs > View Installed Updates.

Can you confirm that you can do so? If yes, just attach the C:\Windows\Patches\PatchAgent.log file from the remediation target to this ticket directly, no SFTP required. That should confirm whether there is a 100% confirmed block on the server or if Apache is simply not responding. Did you try a LanGuard server reboot as I recommended?

Best regards,
Keyur Saxena
GFI - LanGuard Support Team

Kayako - ticket id 60252140 // Randall Shawver commented publicly: Dear Jonard,

Thank you for contacting the GFI - LanGuard Support Team.

First, please check a few of the remote computers to ensure they are not showing the error "You are no longer entitled to product updates". If these errors are present, you must push the batch file to all computers with an agent installed.

Fixing the "You are no longer entitled to product updates" error in program updates for agents - GFI LanGuard [https://gfi-languard-supportdesk.kayako.com/article/128478-fixing-the-you-are-no-longer-entitled-to-product-updates-error-in-program-updates-for-agents]

If the above issue is not present, please perform a Manual Update of Languard [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/123069-updating-languard-server-manually-when-unable-to-get-current-updates-or-agents-do-not-pull-latest-definitions-from-server] before attempting the deployment again.

If the issue persists, then follow Gather Troubleshooter Logs from GFI LanGuard Agent [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/123171-providing-troubleshooter-logs-from-gfi-languard-agent] and Providing Troubleshooter Logs from GFI LanGuard Server - GFI LanGuard [https://gfi-languard-supportdesk.kayako.com/article/122371-providing-troubleshooter-logs-from-gfi-languard-server] to provide the logs from the server and from one agent computer. Enter the ticket number as GFI-000060-252140 when prompted. Provide specific details about the failure for this computer.

Share them here to facilitate continued troubleshooting. There are different methods to provide the logs if the automatic upload fails. If less than 50 megs, upload the logs directly to this ticket.

Upload Files via FTP

Open a new Windows Explorer window and navigate to: ftp://ftp.gfisoftware.com

Go to File > Login As, or right-click on the window and click Login and enter the following credentials:

Username: gfi

Password: gfi911cust

Drag or copy and paste the zipped log files into the blank pane.

Once the uploads have finished, send an email to your GFI Support representative with the name used for the zip files.

Use Google drive or another file sharing service to upload the logs and provide the download link.

Go to www.wetransfer.com. Click the Take me to free link. Agree to terms. Click the … button next to the Transfer button and select Create Link. Click the … button to close. Click Add files to add the files. Click Transfer. Please provide the download link.

We look forward to hearing from you again.

Best regards,
Randall Shawver
GFI - LanGuard Support Team

According to their statement: “If you are seeing the timeout even after setting the maximum timeout in the remediation options (6000s), but the patch is still deploying successfully, we are currently unable to increase the timeout further in the product.  Button selection: [I don't have the license key handy] 

--- AI Assistant ---

 Given your reseller/distributor status, that's alright, so let's get down to business! 🛟 

--- AI Assistant ---

 If you have any 📃 log files or 🖼️ screenshots to upload to help with the troubleshooting, now is the time to do it 💪

ℹ️ When you select to upload files, a new window will open to our secure portal allowing you to upload the attachments.

ℹ️ When you are done uploading files, come back to this window to continue the flow.

👉 Secure File Upload [https://files.eswsecuretransfers.com/customers?token=eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiIsInR5cCI6IkpXVCJ9..PJRfljRXSJxjnSfcB-vB0Y0YPcyuJ7Ac7ZQ7ic7hlfc]

You should see the following:

 	* User: jumerez@ai-cs.com
 	* Session ID: 87f7ab68-923c-44df-ad70-d836cf3fc390

--- Customer (Jonard Umerez) ---

 Button selection: [🔙 Continue without file upload ] 

--- AI Assistant ---

 No worries! Let's tackle this deployment timeout issue together. 😊

I found some really helpful information about this exact problem. The Timed out: The Patch Agent did not respond in the permitted time interval error is actually pretty common when deploying large packages or service packs with GFI LanGuard.

Here's the good news: the patch may actually still be installing successfully on the target machine even though you're seeing the timeout error. The timeout just means the installation didn't complete within the configured time limit, but the patch agent continues working in the background.

Let me walk you through the main solutions:

1. INCREASE THE DEPLOYMENT TIMEOUT

The default timeout is 10 minutes, which can be too short for large packages. Here's how to increase it:

 	* Go to the GFI LanGuard Console and select Remediate
 	* Choose the computers/groups to patch and select the patch(es) you want to deploy
 	* Click the Remediate... button
 	* Select the Advanced Options hyperlink (or click the third Customize hyperlink, then click Advanced)
 	* Increment the value for Deployment Timeout (maximum is 6000 seconds)
 	* Check Remember settings to make this change permanent
 	* Click OK to run the job

2. VERIFY HTTP COMMUNICATIONS AREN'T BLOCKED

Make sure the agent can access the LanGuard server's communication port (default is 1072):

 	* From the agent machine, open: http://<LanguardServerIP>:1072/files/update/index.txt
 	* Or test with telnet: telnet <LanGuard_IP> 1072

If the port isn't responding, you'll need to configure your firewall to allow TCP/IP traffic on port 1072.

Could you tell me what timeout value you currently have configured, and approximately how large is the package you're trying to deploy? This will help me guide you to the right timeout setting.

📚 Source: Resolving Patch Deployment Timeout Error [https://support.languard.gfi.com/article/122760] 

--- Customer (Jonard Umerez) ---

 create a ticket for this 

--- AI Assistant ---

 Absolutely, I can help you get connected with our support team to create a ticket for this deployment timeout issue.
